comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Quasymody this one is for you, I hope it is of some help?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Taken from Bennelong Point looking SW - bit of an unusual angle.  

This is the photo Quasymody is trying to prove ISN'T the RMS CHINA (for very complicated reasons to do with dating a panorama) - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5352424755/]

I would say it is definitely NOT the CHINA from the different arrangement of bridge and foremast.

The panorama drama -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4350240764/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: This photo seems to be between 1899 (The CAMEO cigarettes advert) and 1903 when the Harbour Trust Building was built - it should show behind the bridge if it was there.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
1897 view of RMS CHINA - see slightly different bridge -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/8292113725/]

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Wow this is good! Wonderful detail on the higher resolution versions. Port side as well! Thanx!!!

 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] has even come up with a date range pronto!

 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] also keep in mind that RMS China evidently underwent major refit in 1898-1900...so the 1897 pic is maybe not all that helpful here...the comparison should be made with the ship seen in the pic taken from the Dawes Point chimney...but in any case I agree that this ANMM pic confirms the Sydney Mail caption was incorrect and that the ship in question wasn't RMS China...which we knew had to be the case from the shipping intelligence...but seeing is believing!

Want to have a go at identifying the ship in the Dawes Point pic?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Glad it was useful. Saw the words 'port side' in the original description & got excited :) [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thanks for all the additional info, all the dating you two have done by old city advertisements is really interesting!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/35672655@N00] identifies the Carrington St skyscraper (the Wynyard Building) here www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4350240764/ ; I gather we see the Wynyard Building here...though from the southern side www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363533740/ ; here's the SMH report of its demise in 1928 ...there's a grainy pic of the fire brigade in action on the following page nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16434229

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] I have a strong feeling the ship we are trying to find out about is the RMS MOLDAVIA (1) P&O (1903).  See my comments over here - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5352424755/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Some of the problem with the RMS CHINA photos is that there was also a contemporary "SS CHINA" (1889) Pacific Mail Steamship Company, which operated between San Francisco, Yokahama, Hawaii and Hong Kong. It seems that photos of our RMS CHINA have crept into the wrong places, particularly this website - www.atlantictransportline.us/content/60China.htm . Apart from the masts and bridge differences, the anchor chain hole at the bow is not something they would be likely to change at a refit. A "RMS CHINA" wikipedia article to sort it all out?

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Every ship should be allocated its own bar code!
